head.title: The Last Speech. A Satire11 First published in Poems (1794), pp. 23-28.

div.head: Argument
div.p: [In the month of June 1792, an uncommon rumour was spread around Edinburgh, of Mad Dogs. and of people being bit by them—A reward of one shilling for the head of every dog that was killed, was offered; tempted by which, many idle and cruel people took upon them the trade of Dog-killing.—Influenced by the example of the magistrates of the metropolis, the same measures were adopted by many of the inferior towns in Scotland, and many thousands of these faithful animals suffered, though innocent, and far from the contagion, if any such was then in existence. We shall suppose one of them at the place of execution, pleading his own cause, and enveighing against his persecutors.]

lg.l: Where Nausau 22 [GT's note: The Statue of King William.] Presented to the city of Glasgow in 1735, the statue of the protestant king of England, Scotland and Ireland, William III, is among the oldest in Scotland and stood in Trongate until 1897 after which time it was moved to Glasgow Cross railway station; today it stands in Cathedral Square. on a gallant steed
Rides day and night, but makes no speed;
Where Glasgow merchants, rich as Jews,
Resort to hear and tell the news;
And councils, as old Athens’ wise,
Thousands of mighty schemes devise,
As, police guards to take up rogues,
And laws enact for hanging dogs;—
Upon the rail that guards the King,
Poor Colly, fasten’d in a string,
Sans jury, doom’d to suffer death,
Thus utter’d, with his latest breath—
“What have I done that I should die?
If I must swing pray tell me why?
Did I e’er bite, or rob, or kill,
Or blood of innocence e’er spill?
Or did I e’er oppress the poor,
Or drive the beggar from the door?
Or break the trust I ought to keep,
Or kill the hens, or worry sheep?
If I’ve done these, then let me die!
If not, thus cursed noose untie.
Although I never was a mad dog,
I must confess I’ve been a sad dog!
And such a wanton canine rover
Lives not ’tween John O’Grots’33 I.e., John o’ Groats, the northernmost point of the Scottish mainland. and Dover!44 Town and ferry port located in southeast England.
But were men hang’d for such a thing,
The gravest of you all would swing.
Yet, ere I die, let me endeavour,
To do mankind one signal favour;
For, as by instinct, ’tis confest,
One brute should know another best,
I’ll point out with exactest care
The dogs of whom you should beware:—
For these blood-hounds, who drag’d me hither,
Well I may call each of them brother—
They’re worse than dogs, for I can say
My master I did ne’er betray;
But they, for sake of one poor shilling,
Leave off their work for Colly killing:
And did the law like sanction give,
Their fellow-mortals to bereave
Of life—and deny it if you can—
For six-pence more they’d kill a man!

Not far from hence a kennel stands,55 [GT's note: The Council-Chamber.] Until 1814 the Tolbooth located in the middle of what is today Glasgow Cross served as the Council Chambers and site of public hangings.
Where scent-dogs gather oft in bands;
Mischief their trade, and night and day
They watch incessant for their prey;
Swift are their legs, and soon their snout
Can smell the hapless Debtor out:
Come not their magic paws within,
But shun each dog with scarlet skin.66 Reluctance by tracker dogs to discover rich or diseased miscreants.
The oldest canus of our race,
Not far from hence maintains a place;
For since the Heath’nish system’s o’er,
And Tartarus77 In Greek mythology, part of the underworld where the wicked suffer punishment for their misdeeds on earth. is known no more,
This Cerberus88 In Greek mythology, the three-headed watchdog of Hades. was sent to earth,
And here obtain’d a jailor’s birth:
But somewhat diff’rent in his mode;
For, none e’er saw hell’s grim abode,
’Till he his triple jaws did ope,
And each was silenc’d with a sop;
But here, the case is alter’d quite,
You enter without sop or bite
His hell on earth;—but this ne’er doubt,
By heav’n! you’ll pay e’re you get out.
Another set there is, though tied up,
Who puff’d with wealth and lordly pride up,
Like rev’rend signiors walk the street,
And curl their nose at all they meet;
And when they issue forth their will,
It valid stands, or good, or ill:
But none would for an hundred dollars,
Attack those dogs with golden collars.99 [GT's note: A mark of civic authority.] Heavy gold chain worn as insignia of office or as a mark of fealty.
As men, before their dissolution,
Are us’d to make a distribution
Of all their goods and gear, so I
With this old fashion’d form comply:
And as my wealth, nay never doubt me,
Is only what I have about me;
Which, that my ’foresaid brethren may get,
The following articles I legate:—
First, to my murd’rers I bequeath
My curish nature and my teeth.
Next, to the kennel, what was mine
Of scent and swiftness I resign.
Item, to Cerb’rus, that fell Grecian,
I leave my greedy disposition.
But to the last, what shall I grant?
It must be something that they want—
My tongue—no—that can never be—
I’ll leave them my sagacity.
And now—but ah! I plead in vain!
Nought can your cruelty restrain;
Since, I for majesterial fury,
Must suffer without judge or jury.”
